subject: Re: [junit] ClassNotFoundException, sometimes
msgSnippet: James: I tried your suggestions (-verbose), but discovered that my problem has mysteriously disappeared. With or without the -verbose option, I can run ant
messageBody:
James:

I tried your suggestions (-verbose), but discovered that my problem has mysteriously disappeared.

With or without the -verbose option, I can run "ant test" multiple times in a row without problems.

I have made no changes to the code since I last saw the problem. I have rebooted since then, so my best guess is that the reboot may have had something to do with making the problem go away (at least for now). Just a guess.

Thanks for your suggestions.

David

James Abley wrote:
>
>
>
> 2009/5/6 David Rush <david@... <mailto:david%40rushtone.com>>:
>>
>>
>> David:
>>
>> I created Foo.java, which simply has a main method that creates an
> exception
>> object from the 3rd-party library and prints it out:
>>
>> import com.esri.sde.sdk.client.*;
>> public class Foo {
>> public static void main(String[] args) {
>> System.out.println("Foo");
>> SeException ex = new SeWarningException("Testing");
>> System.out.println("ex = "+ex);
>> }
>> }
>>
>> and a foo task in my build.xml
>>
>> <target name="foo" depends="compile">
>> <java classname="Foo" classpathref="test.classpath" />
>> </target>
>>
>> It does not exhibit the puzzling behavior. I can run "ant foo" multiple
>> times in succession without problems. I added "compile.tests" to "depends"
>> in the foo task, and it makes no difference (I can still run foo multiple
>> times in a row without problems).
>>
>> If I do this from the command line:
>> ant clean
>> ant test
>> ant test
>>
>> I get a failure on the 2nd "ant test".
>> If I do this:
>> ant clean
>> ant foo
>> ant test
>> ant foo
>>
>> I get a failure on the "ant test" (ant compile and both runs of ant
> foo work
>> fine).
>>
>> compile.tests is this:
>>
>> <target name="compile.tests" depends="compile">
>> <mkdir dir="build/classes" />
>> <javac
>> srcdir="src_tests"
>> destdir="build/classes"
>> classpathref="test.classpath"
>> debug="on" debuglevel="lines,vars,source"
>> deprecation="yes"
>>>
>> <!--
>> <compilerarg value="-Xlint:all"/>
>> -->
>> <compilerarg value="-Xmaxerrs"/> <compilerarg value="${error_count.max}"/>
>> <compilerarg value="-Xmaxwarns"/> <compilerarg
>> value="${warning_count.max}"/>
>> <compilerarg value="-version"/>
>> </javac>
>> </target>
>>
>> David
>
> Try the verbose and debug output mode of ant to see if you get more
> information?
>
>>
>> David Saff wrote:
>>>
>>>
>>>
>>> I'd be suspicious of what "compile.tests" is doing. If you create a
>>> short main() class that depends on the class in question, and an ant
>>> target that runs it, do you see the same behavior?
>>>
>>> David Saff
>>>
>>> On Tue, May 5, 2009 at 4:27 PM, David Rush <david@...
> <mailto:david%40rushtone.com>
>>> <mailto:david%40rushtone.com>> wrote:
>>>> I'm working on setting up some junit test cases for an application
>>> that's been around a while. I have some tests running via ant, but I
>>> have a strange situation.
>>>>
>>>> When use "ant clean" to delete all the compiled classes, then "ant
>>> test" (which depends on the compile task, so it'll compile before it
>>> runs the tests) to run the junit tests (via the junit ant task), it
>>> works fine. The code compiles and the junit tests work.
>>>>
>>>> However, if I immediately run "ant test" to re-run the junit tests, it
>>> fails with a NoClassDefFoundError, complaining about not being able to
>>> find a particular class in a 3rd-party library I'm using. The correct
>>> .jar file for the library is in the classpath.
>>>>
>>>> If I do "ant clean", then "ant test" it works.
>>>>
>>>> Any ideas?
>>>>
>>>> Here's the "test" snippet from my ant script:
>>>>
>>>> <target name="test" depends="compile.tests" description="Runs JUnit
>>> tests">
>>>> <junit printsummary="false" haltonfailure="true" showoutput="true">
>>>> <classpath refid="test.classpath"/>
>>>> <formatter type="brief" usefile="false"/>
>>>> <batchtest>
>>>> <fileset dir="build/classes" includes="**/*.class"/>
>>>> </batchtest>
>>>> </junit>
>>>> </target>
>>>>
>>>> David
>>>>
>>>>
>>>> ------------------------------------
>>>>
>>>> Yahoo! Groups Links
>>>>
>>>>
>>>>
>>>>
>>>
>>>
>>
>
>
